awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Leveraging the Three-Dimensional Multi-Stability from Origami Folding to Synthesize Multi-Functional Material Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) award supports fundamental research to derive a novel approach to harness three-dimensional multi-stability induced by origami folding for engineering multi-functional material systems.  These material systems can potentially bear mechanical loads but also perform other duties.  The research aims at transforming the ancient art of origami into a theoretical framework for designing multi-functional materials.  It is envisioned that these multi-functional origami materials can significantly advance the performance and sustainability of many strategic applications like morphing airframes, adaptive wind turbines, energy harvesters, and medical devices.   Origami folding - due to its seemingly infinite capabilities of developing 3D geometries from 2D sheets - is becoming an increasingly popular subject among mathematicians, educators, architects, and engineers.  However, we are still scratching the surface of its potential.  The research will formulate a systematic method: analysis, design, and experiment, to fully uncover the physics underpinning the 3D multi-stability from folding.   Such physical insights will be exploited to create linkages to translate these stability properties into unprecedented material functions, such as on-demand property programming, static diode effects, and motion rectification.  Research results will also be leveraged to enhance origami as an engaging teaching tool through the creation of a book of origami folding exercises for teaching engineering. The research will also lead to a Creative Inquiry project for undergraduates, in collaboration with the Clemson Engineers for Developing Countries program, on the design of origami emergency shelters in Haiti. This project will produce educational tools that are specifically designed to be adopted by other educators to train high-quality researchers and engineers as well as to motivate K-12 students to pursue undergraduate and graduate STEM study. The research outcomes of this project will enable new low-cost material systems to adaptively protect infrastructure systems from natural and man-made disasters and to increase the collection of energy from renewable sources.

Multi-stability has been used to create many multi-functional materials and structures for shape reconfiguration, property adaptation, vibration control, and energy harvesting.  However, current systems are built upon low dimensional mechanisms such as the buckled beams, the simplicity of which severely limits their overall potential.   This CAREER award aims to leverage the mechanics of origami folding to advance the study of multi-stable systems into the fundamentally three-dimensional domain. The sophisticated shape transformations via folding can impart novel stability properties that are unavailable in the lower dimensional mechanisms, including the anisotropic arrangement of stable and unstable states, asymmetric energy barrier between stable states, and the use of pressurization to eliminate or create stable equilibria.  This project will formulate nonlinear mechanics analysis, experiment validation, and crease design methodologies to harness these stability properties and synthesize architected multi-functional material systems.  This project, if successful, will create a new field of three-dimensional multi-stability, including a high-fidelity mechanics modeling process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past decades, we have witnessed the rapid emergence of origami as a versatile design and fabrication platform for incubating engineering innovations. The original ideas of origami were simple and elegant: One can fold and manipulate a piece of paper using a pre-designed crease pattern to create decorative 3D shapes, like paper cranes and boats. This folk art originated in East Asia centuries ago and has mostly remained the same. The first breakthrough occurred after World War II, as artists and mathematicians developed new folding techniques and mathematical theories for designing and analyzing folding. As a result, we saw an explosion in the beauty and complexity of origami. The seemingly infinite possibility of creating 3D shapes out of 2D flat precursors quickly attracts attention from scientists and engineers, evolving origami into a broad research discipline.

Since the first breakthrough in origami research occurred in their design and folding kinematics, it is not surprising that their early engineering adoptions also focused on exploiting shape transformations via folding. That is, the origami sheets were treated like 3D linkage mechanisms. The deployable solar panels for spacecraft, kinetic building facades, and paper packaging are great examples of folding kinematics put in use.

However, since around 2010, we have witnessed a paradigm shift in origami research. The focus has moved away from pure kinematics and into the mechanics. This shift has led to a new way of analyzing origami, treating them more like elastic membranes or shells with folds and cuts rather than linkages. With such a paradigm shift, the breadth and depth of origami-inspired engineering studies quickly reached a new level.

The overarching vision of this CAREER project is to accelerate and complete this paradigm shift. The outcome of this project can be organized into three highlights:

  1. A deeper understanding of the elastic and dynamic deformation of origami
  2. A broader exploration of using multi-stable origami for making advanced materials and robots
  3. A wider public outreach with origami as a STEM educational tool

In what follows, we report these outcomes in more detail.

Regarding the fundamental mechanics of origami, we all faced a critical challenge: a need for high-fidelity yet computation-efficient models. To this end, we have substantially contributed to formulating new mechanics/dynamic models using different approaches, including the rigid-facet and spring-hinge approach, the bar-hinge approach, and the more advanced Absolute Nodal Coordinate Formulation (ANCF) approach. The highlight here is the ANCF. We are happy to report that the new ANCF model accurately simulates transient dynamic origami deformations involving complex and non-uniform folding. It is also more efficient than the commercial finite element software package ABAQUS because it requires an order of magnitude less degree of freedom to converge. With these models, we provide origami research communities with more capable analytical tools.

Our research outcomes also exemplified the versatility of multi-stable origami (aka origami that can settle into different folding configurations without any external aids). For example, by stacking multiple and 3D-printed Miura-ori sheets, one can create a cellular solid that can adapt its effective Young's modulus simply by folding to different stable states.

A kirigami sheet (a relative of origami with cutting in addition to folding) can exhibit Braggs elastic wave propagation bandgaps, which are programmable by sequencing its bistable "bits" between 0 and 1 states. One can also assemble two bistable origami modules into an earthworm-like robot. This dual-segment robot can exhibit a deterministic deformation sequence, leading to peristaltic-like locomotion gaits without digital controllers.

Finally, we frequently attend different public outreach events and showcase origami engineering. From the "Artshpere" festival at Greenville City (a thriving manufacturing hub in South Carolina), a middle school in Rural Virginia, to a large STEM conference in the heart of our national capital, we set up booths and fold origami together with school-aged children and their parents. Through these folds, we teach them some fundamental engineering lessons.

The beauty and elegance of origami have attracted the attention of researchers from many different disciplines. The future success of this field will continue to hinge upon the synergy of broad research collaborations. The many graduate and undergraduate students supported by this project will play an active role in this vibration field in the future.
